column1: Reorganize repository to make room for more smart contracts

column1: Implement a dynamic Grid front-end which will display blockchain data of any RecordType
column26:
The existing [Track and Trace|https://github.com/hyperledger/grid-contrib/tree/master/track_and_trace] client implementations are hard-coded for one RecordType ("fish", and "assets"). A more dynamic client which pulls builds a UI appropriate to any RecordType out of the box would make setting up Grid demos considerably easier. This client could then become the canonical example, replacing both the fish and asset versions.

 

Full specification for the Universal Client can be found in its original RFC. Note that while it was written with the old Sawtooth Supply Chain project in mind, it applies more or less as-is to Grid:
 [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-rfcs/blob/master/text/0014-supply-chain-universal-client.md]
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Replace the existing JS ledger sync with a Rust implementation
column26: The existing [Track and Trace ledger sync|https://github.com/hyperledger/grid-contrib/tree/master/track_and_trace/ledger_sync] (aka state delta export) is implemented in JavaScript/Node.js. In order to bring this component in line with the rest of the Grid repo, it should be refactored into Rust. The refactor should be fully functionally equivalent to the existing JS implementation.
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Replace the existing JS Server with a Rust implementation
column26: The existing implementation of the [Track and Trace server|https://github.com/hyperledger/grid-contrib/tree/master/track_and_trace/server] (aka REST API) has been implemented in JavaScript/Node.js. In order to bring this component in-line with the rest of the Grid repo, it should be refactored into Rust and added to the Grid daemon (which currently uses Actix).
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: 2019-03 license scanning results
column26: Issues to address from the latest software license scan. The attached .txt file has the notes, the attached .xls has the details, the attached .spdx file is for scripts to chew on.
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column96:
21/May/19 11:54 PM;amundson;Copying the "notes" out of the attached text file:

Notes for grid scan 2019-03-27:

1) In grid-rfcs, the LICENSE-APACHE and README.md files state that the repository is licensed under Apache-2.0. However, it appears that grid-rfcs is intended to be primarily a documentation repository -- is that correct? If so, the project license for grid-rfcs should likely be Creative Commons Attribution 4.0, also called CC-BY-4.0, rather than Apache-2.0.

2) In the "No license found" tab of the spreadsheet, the files with "No license found" do not contain license notices that were detected from our scanning. Where possible, for those that contain Hyperledger code, Apache-2.0 comments should be added. This can be done by adding a comment with an SPDX short-form identifier, such as:

    SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0

Note that the files in this tab listed as "third party directory", "excluded file extension" or "empty file" do not need to have these notices added.

3) Creative Commons Attribution 4.0, CC-BY-4.0, is the license for Hyperledger documentation. Consider adding notices to any Hyperledger documentation files, such as:

    SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0

More information for #2 and #3 can be found on the Hyperledger wiki, at https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/HYP/Copyright+and+License+Policy
;;;
column97:
21/May/19 11:57 PM;amundson;Re: "1) In grid-rfcs, the LICENSE-APACHE and README.md files state that the repository is licensed under Apache-2.0. However, it appears that grid-rfcs is intended to be primarily a documentation repository – is that correct? If so, the project license for grid-rfcs should likely be Creative Commons Attribution 4.0, also called CC-BY-4.0, rather than Apache-2.0."

Apache 2.0 in that repository is intentional as we want the concepts contributed to be under that license.;;;

column1: Add Grid Product Smart Contract
column26:
Implement the Grid Product smart contract and add it to the grid/contract registry. 

This story includes the following:
 * Add grid product addressing, state, -and payload proto files-
 * -*Add rust native implementations to the grid SDK protocols*-
 * Implement the smart contract so it can be run in Sabre
 * Add unit tests using a MockTransactionContext (see grid schema for example, use sawtooth-sdk 0.3 and sabre sdk 0.2)
 * Add a Sabre contract file (see [https://github.com/hyperledger/grid/blob/ca9f19ff74ba8dec53e08a8e3a07d001c5f08573/contracts/schema/schema.yaml] for example)
 * Add Dockerfile and add deploying the contract to Sabre in the docker-compose files

|*Review*| * Address Rust native refactor of Grid SDK by updating relevant database fields, tables, and schemas
 * Update state-delta-subscriber components to utilize product db schemas/models
 * PR: [https://github.com/hyperledger/grid/pull/113]|

column1: Add Grid Product CLI
column26:
Add the following commands to the Grid CLI:
 * grid product create (create a new product)
 * grid product update (update an existing product)
 * grid product delete (delete an existing product)
 * grid product list (list all products)
 * grid product show (show specific product) 

 

This will require the REST API for Product is already implemented.

column1: Move DB Migrations to CLI
column26:
Move the DB migration execution from gridd to a grid cli subcommand.  This should allow for an admin (with different permissions in the db instance) to run the migrations, and the grid daemon can be locked down to just reading/writing from the existing tables.

 

-The grid daemon should, however, know if it requires a migration, log an error and exit.- This check will be completed as part of a separate story:  [GRID-87|https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/GRID-87]

column96:
21/Jun/19 1:46 AM;mattp;As I'm trying to use the documentation guide, I'm struggling with understanding the guide in the context of the decision maker role.  Basically I'm looking at this subset of info from [the guide|https://docs.google.com/document/d/11rgfuRu7c-tzcsSzsVQAoCgWBGrt6jEWzO-b_txi_hs/edit?ts=5cf68be6#heading=h.j8j13kuztut4[]|https://docs.google.com/document/d/11rgfuRu7c-tzcsSzsVQAoCgWBGrt6jEWzO-b_txi_hs/edit?ts=5cf68be6#heading=h.j8j13kuztut4] as it relates to the decision maker role. 

 

The basic subset of info I'm trying to follow from the guide:

 

Entry Template

The entries for the following role sections should follow one of the following templates:

 

A *_decision maker_* must understand *_the intent and scope of Hyperledger Grid._*

A _*decision maker*_ must be able to follow a procedure to do *_<task to be documented>_* 

A *_decision maker_* must understand how to *_<do task>_* using the *_<Grid component>._*

A *_decision maker_* must understand how to *_<do task>._*

A _*decision maker*_ must be able to troubleshoot problems with to *_<task to be documented>_*.

 

Where *_<role>_* is a member of the audience the documentation is for.

 

For example:

 

A *_decision maker_* must understand *_Grid at a very high level._*

 

The entry should be short and specific. If a procedure is large, split it into subtasks. Use this format:

 
 * A *_decision maker_* must understand how to *<do task>* using *<Grid component>*_._

            *<subtasks>*
 * A *_decision maker_* must understand *_<information that must be documented>_*.
 * A _*decision maker*_ must be able to follow a procedure to *_<task to be documented>_*.
 * A _*decision maker*_ must be able to troubleshoot problems with *_<task to be documented>_*.

 
h2. Decision maker (“business stakeholders”)

This user decides whether to use Grid for a POC or production network and directs a team of project leaders (architects), sysadmins, network/smart contract admins, and application developers.

Tasks:
 * Understand Grid at a very high level (with beautiful diagrams)
 * Decide if their team should try Grid
 * Determine the general resources for a POC (people)

 

 

If the decision maker is trying to decide to try Grid (as mentioned above), you don't actually decide to try Grid given that Grid is positioned as a framework and not an application.  However, a decision maker may decide to use Grid Product or one of the other Grid applications being built on top of the framework.  In addition, a decision maker may also decide to develop an application on top of Grid or while using the Grid framework, but that would be dependent on the context of their use case, applicability to Grid, and state of development of other functions, components, and primitives within the Grid framework.   For this story specifically, it might be best to lay out the differences here between the framework and applications being built on top, and rationalize the difference between them, and curate a 1 page summary (providing visual and context) of the value prop for both layers (framework and application).  Thoughts here?  Looking for feedback on my approach and if I'm heading astray from the spirit of this story.  [~agunde] [~amundson];;;
column97: 02/Jul/19 6:07 AM;mattp;I think we should create stories for the intended platform where the documentation would reside.  For example, I think we should have separate stories for what documentation would be on the project webpage, grid developer documentation, and handout or summary info for marketing purposes.  I've created a bunch of offline documentation but struggle where to put it for feedback.  I can dump it here, but think it's more applicable for feedback and iteration in the context of the location in which it would reside.;;;
column98: 04/Jul/19 7:20 AM;mattp;Hey [~agunde] - I updated the documentation plan document and included my initial thoughts as previously discussed. Let me know what feedback you or others have.  Thanks!;;;

column1: Flesh out Profile page on Track and Trace UIs
column26: Currently the track and trace UIs (AssetTrack and FishNet) only show the Pike agent information on the profile. This page should also pull in the User's information from the tnt server to show email and allow password updates.
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Fix get started resource creation order in Track and Trace UIs
column26:
Currently, the Get Started page in the Track and Trace UIs has a bug which allows users to be created before the agent transaction is committed. This means that if the transaction fails, a user will exist in the system but it will not be associated with an agent.

The logic should be fixed so that the user is only created if the create agent transaction is valid. It also needs to handle the case where the agent info is valid but the user information (such as the supplied email) is invalid.
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Write Gridd key management RFC
column26:
Write an RFC describing a process for user authentication and key management.

This process will allow you to create a user account which stores an encrypted "wallet" of private keys, as well as your username/email and hashed password. You should be able to send your auth credentials to Gridd to retrieve your wallet.
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Check if migrations were run in Daemon startup
column26:
The database migrations should be run via the Grid CLI before the Grid Daemon (gridd) starts up.
The gridd should check if the migrations were run when its starts up, log an error and exit. The error message should include instructions to the user to run the migrations via the CLI.  

This task will be easy to complete if/when this PR in Diesel is merged:
[https://github.com/diesel-rs/diesel/pull/1846]

Otherwise this task has to be completed manually.  An example of how that might be accomplished can be found here:
[https://github.com/big-neon/bn-api/pull/941/files]
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Implement Block ID queries in Grid REST API
column26:
Each GET route in the REST API should include a block ID query parameter.

With this functionality, clients can request the data that is true at a certain block height, rather than only getting data for the most recently committed block. This can be implemented as a filter where:
{{start_block_num <= request_block_height < end_block_num}}

Note that the query param should be a Block ID rather than a block num/block height, since a fork could cause a certain block num to refer to a different version of state than what was requested.

The default behavior (no Block ID param supplied) should still get the data for the most recent block.
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Implement paging in Grid REST API
column26:
Each list route in the REST API should include paging parameters, and responses should include a paging object to easily fetch the next page.

For example, the query for records could be:

`/record?limit=25&offset=50`
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Grid Daemon event processor enters repeated values for TnT reported values
column26:
Every time the Grid Daemon receives an event to update a property value for an existing record, it adds to the database not only the updated value, but all the previous values that were stored in the same PropertyPage.

The Grid Deamon should be changed to add only the updated value.  

Location of the bug: 
[https://github.com/hyperledger/grid/blob/49dcd660dbf44f34bd513ae5d8dc652845520f2a/daemon/src/event/block.rs#L290]

column1: Rename Grid Product "product_type" field
column26:
Rename the _*product_type*_ field to *_product_namespace_*

**Essentially, "type" is an overloaded term, so we opted for "namespace" since it would nicely align with Grid's address namespace-prefixing for different kinds of products.

For more detail, read the [RocketChat discussion|https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/grid?msg=uaeKLw7rFoB87ekdi]
column57: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Rename Grid Product "UNSET_TYPE" enum
column26:
Rename the *UNSET_TYPE* field to *UNSET_NAMESPACE*

**Essentially, "type" is an overloaded term, so we opted for "namespace" since it would nicely align with Grid's address namespace-prefixing for different kinds of product standards.

Read this related discussion in [RocketChat|https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/grid?msg=uaeKLw7rFoB87ekdi]
